ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

NEW CONSTITUTION FOR SINGAPORE


    1. Mr Lim Cher Kheng asked the Chief Minister whether the necessary legislation for the introduction of the new Constitution for Singapore has been finalised; and whether he can state when the Order of Her Majesty in Council containing the new Constitution will be made.

    2. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Chief Minister:

    (a) when was the draft of the proposed new Constitution for Singapore received by the Singapore Government.

    (b) are there any aspects in the draft of the proposed new Constitution which call for further negotiations, and if he will identify them; and

    (c) whether he has been in correspondence with the Colonial Office in London during the past year in connection with these aspects, and if he will present the correspondence to this House.

Column: 17



    3. Mr Lee Kuan Yew asked the Chief Minister whether he has received from London a draft of the Constitution of the new State of Singapore, and when other parties who participated in the London talks will receive copies of the draft for their approval.

    4. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Chief Minister whether he will give this House an opportunity to debate the desirability of a proposed further all-Party Mission to London in connection with the proposed new Constitution for Singapore; and if he will give an estimate of the probable expense to be borne by this territory in connection with the proposed Mission.

    5. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Chief Minister whether there has been correspondence between the Singapore Government and the Colonial Office in London arising out of the rejection by this Assembly last year of the anti-subversive clause in the Report of the Constitutional Conference held in London in March and April 1957 and whether he will present such correspondence to this House.

    The Chief Minister (Dr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, as there are a number of questions on today's Order Paper on the subject of the Constitutional Order in Council, with your permission I shall answer Nos. 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 at the same time.

    The constitutional instruments are still being drafted in the Colonial Office and I hope that the completed draft will be received here by the end of this month. I have myself recently discussed the drafting with Mr Melville of the Colonial Office during his visit to Singaport, and certain sections have been referred to our local experts for checking and revision. As soon as the completed draft is ready, I shall study it in conjunction with the members of the All-Party Delegation who were signatories to the conference report.

    The stand taken by the Assembly on the anti-subversive clause was reported to the Secretary of State. No correspondence between this Government and the Colonial Office was entered into on this matter, nor has this Government

Column: 18

entered into any correspondence with the Colonial Office on the drafting of the Constitution.

    The introduction of the new Constitution can be effected at any time this Assembly considers that the time has come to address the Governor to fix a date for the new Constitution in accordance with the agreement set out in paragraph 54 of the Report of the Singapore Constitutional Conference, 1957.

    I would invite the attention of hon. Members to that part of the Governor's speech delivered on 9th April which reads as follows:

    "The Government intends that the agreement with the United Kingdom Government on the form of the constitutional instruments should be made by the All-Party delegation which took part in the Constitutional discussion last year."
The constitutional instruments deal with the life and future of the new State of Singapore and cannot be framed to the satisfaction of local political Parties and the local Government on the one side, and the United Kingdom Government some 8,000 miles away, without delay and without the risk of losing that unity so desirable for such a vital business save by discussions by the parties concerned. I have therefore made arrangements with the Colonial Office for such discussions to take place in May, and I propose to invite the same members to London to finalise the constitutional instruments. The probable expense to Singapore is return air passages for six persons plus necessary incidentals.

    The desirability of visiting London for this purpose cannot be gainsaid and I do not consider it necessary that this Assembly should be given an opportunity to debate this matter.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Will the Hon. the Chief Minister confirm that copies of this draft constitution have been circulating or are being circulated to some heads of Government Departments?

    The Chief Minister: Sir, I said in my reply just now that certain sections of the draft Constitution have been referred but not full copies. As it is, I myself have not seen a completed copy.

Column: 19



    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Is that because the Chief Minister is not in the confidence of Her Majesty's Colonial Office?

    The Chief Minister: I do not know whether that is to my credit or to my discredit.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Does the Chief Minister remember that in London it was agreed that the terms of the constitutional instruments setting out what was agreed to in the Report of the All-Party Committee were to be settled by the Delegation and the Parties that the Delegation represented?

    The Chief Minister: I said, Sir, that when the complete draft is received by me, there will be consultations with members of the All-Party Delegation, and I also drew attention to that part of the Governor's speech which clearly sets out that this Government will do nothing about the draft Constitution without bringing in the All-Party Delegation.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng (Changi): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to know whether the Hon. the Chief Minister is able to inform this House what is the main cause of the delay in drawing up the draft Constitution. It has taken one solid year already.

    The Chief Minister: I do not know whether I am in a position to reply to that question. It is a matter for the Colonial Office. I understand they have their hands full because there are a number of other Colonies which are having new constitutions almost at the same time as Singapore.

AMENDING LEGISLATION FOR COMPULSORY VOTING IN GENERAL ELECTION


    6. Mr Lim Cher Kheng asked the Chief Minister whether the Government will consider introducing amending legislation for compulsory voting in the forthcoming General Election.

    The Chief Minister: Sir, the answer to this question will depend on the stand which this Assembly is prepared to take when it debates the motion dealing with this subject and standing in the name of the hon. Member for Changi.

Column: 20

LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY ELECTIONS

(New Register of Electors and election date)


    7. Mr Lim Cher Kheng asked the Chief Minister when the new Register of Electors for Legislative Assembly elections under the proposed new Constitution for Singapore will be ready; and what is the earliest practicable date for the holding of a General Election under the new Constitution.

    The Chief Minister: Sir, provided there are no major mechanical breakdowns or other unforeseen difficulties, the Registers of Electors for the Legislative Assembly elections under the proposed new Constitution for Singapore will be ready for inspection by the first week of June 1958. On this timetable, the earliest practicable date for holding elections will be the end of September 1958.

    The answer to the second part of this question is dependent on the stand to be taken by this Assembly when it debates the motion on compulsory voting standing in the name of the hon. Member.

Column: 20

PRESERVATION OF PUBLIC SECURITY ORDINANCE
(Release of detainees)


    8. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Chief Minister whether he will make a statement as to the purpose of requiring persons detained under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance, 1955, and their families to appear before him before the detainees are released.

    The Chief Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, although the Government has been responsible for ordering the detention of certain persons, its attitude to the relatives of the detainees has always been one of sympathy. In some cases, relatives have approached me immediately following the arrest of a member of their family.

    While I cannot interfere with the course of action which Government has taken after very serious and careful consideration for the general good of the people of Singapore, I consider it my

Column: 21

duty, as the head of an elected Government, on the conditional release of these detainees to advise parents, particularly on a personal basis, that they should discharge their duties as parents by looking after the welfare of their sons, and enjoining both parties that they would do well to examine the company they keep in the future.

    This I consider to be my duty, just as I consider it my duty that a detainee should not be detained one minute longer than is necessary if a single doubt exists in my mind of the need for detaining him.

Column: 21

UNEMPLOYMENT FIGURES


    9. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare what is the total number of unemployed persons in Singapore as on 31st January, 1958, giving a breakdown of this figure into:-

    (i) the number of able-bodied persons; and

    (ii) the number of sick and disabled persons.

    The Minister for Labour and Welfare (Dr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, according to Employment Exchange statistics, there were 8,292 unemployed persons in Singapore on 31st January, 1958, of whom 393 were either sick or disabled.

Column: 21

UNEMPLOYED REGISTERED AT LABOUR EXCHANGE
(Steps to secure employment)


    10. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare whether there are persons who have been registered at the Labour Exchange for some years now, who have so far been unable to secure employment; and what steps the Government proposes to take to secure employment for these people as soon as possible.

    Dr Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, the numbers of persons whose names have been on the live register classified by duration of unemployment in respect of periods exceeding six months are as follows: 

  Six months to one year     653 persons

  One year to two years      608   "


Column: 22


  Two to three years ...     211 persons

  Three years and over ...    14   "


    It is considered not profitable to initiate any national scheme for the special purpose of providing employment to the 225 persons who have been unemployed for more than two years, because most of them are unemployable due to old age, to health and to low standards of skill.

SINGAPORE-DUMPING GROUND FOR PROSTITUTES FROM CHINA
(Allegation)


    11. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare what action the Government has taken or intends to take in regard to the statement reported to have been made by. Mrs Shirin Fozdar at the Afro-Asian Conference of women social workers in Colombo alleging that prostitutes from China have dumped themselves in Singapore and that the Colony is now one big brothel.

    Dr Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, a prompt denial to Mrs Shirin Fozdar's statement was made by my Ministry on 22nd February, 1958. I have since interviewed Mrs Fozdar and am satisfied that she had not intended that her statement should be given such a sensational twist.

Column: 22

APPLICATION FOR ENTRY FROM CHINA
(Government policy)


    12. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare if he will make a statement on Government policy with regard to the application for entry into Singapore from China of the wife of a sponsor, resident in Singapore, who has produced documents to prove that his former wife is dead and that his application is in respect of his only wife now living in China.

    Dr Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is Government's policy to admit wives of persons lawfully resident in the Colony. The appropriate regulation to admit such a category of persons is found in paragraph 7 (g) of the Immigration (Prohibition of Entry) Order, 1953. Therefore if the local sponsor in

Column: 23

question has submitted satisfactory evidence to prove (1) that the applicant is his lawful wedded wife, and (2) that his former wife is dead, there is no reason why the application should not be approved, unless in the opinion of the Controller the sponsor has insufficient means to provide for her maintenance.

IMMIGRANTS FROM CHINA FROM JANUARY TO DECEMBER 1957


    Mr Speaker: Question No. 13 has been withdrawn.

    [The following is Question No. 13:

    Mr Lee Choon Eng to ask the Minister for Labour and Welfare if he will state the numbers of persons permitted to enter the Colony from China during the period January to December 1957, under the different categories:-

    (i) wives of residents in the Colony;

    (ii) fathers of residents in the Colony;

    (iii) mothers of residents in the Colony;

    (iv) children of residents in the Colony, and their ages; and

    (v) any others, and their relationship to residents in the Colony.]

NUMBER OF PERSONS ENTERING SINGAPORE FROM
HONGKONG DURING JANUARY/DECEMBER 1957
(Maximum period allowed for stay)


    14. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare if he

Column: 24

will state the number of persons, classified under separate categories such as doctors, songstresses, strip-teasers, etc., permitted to enter the Colony from Hongkong on a temporary visa during the period January to December 1957, and the maximum period allowed for any stay in Singapore.

    Dr Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, the numbers of persons allowed in from Hongkong on temporary passes for the period January to December 1957 are as follows: doctors - nil; songstresses (including dancing troupes and Cantonese wayang troupes) - 183; strip-teasers - none granted as such; business and social visits - 461.

    The normal period allowed for persons on business passes is three months and the maximum period normally granted is under two years.

TRAVEL PASSES BETWEEN SINGAPORE AND FEDERATION


    16. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare whether and when the Government of the Federation of Malaya will require travel passes in respect of persons travelling from Singapore to the Federation of Malaya; and if the Government will consider requiring similar passes for persons entering Singapore from the Federation of Malaya.

    Dr Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have not been officially advised by the Government of the Federation of Malaya that they have decided to institute a system of travel passes for persons travelling from Singapore to the Federation. In the circumstances, the second part of the question, being hypothetical, does not arise.

BANISHMENT ORDINANCE
(Number of detainees)


    17. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Chief Secretary-

    (a) how many persons are at present detained under the Banishment Ordinance (Cap. 127); and

    (b) whether, and how many, persons now detained under the Banishment Ordinance, have been so detained for:-

    (i) more than one year;

Column: 26



    (ii) more than six months and up to one year; and

    (iii) more than three months and up to six months.

    Mr E. B. David: Sir, as on 17th April, there were 35 persons detained under the Banishment Ordinance. The answer to the second part of the Question is 23, 4 and 1 respectively.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng (Queenstown): Sir, can the Hon. the Chief Secretary tell us what is the cause of the long delay in banishing these people?

    Mr E. B. David: That is the subject of a later question, Sir.

BANISHMENT ORDINANCE
(Number of banishees during July/December 1957)


    18. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Chief Secretary how many persons against whom orders of banishment had been issued under the Banishment Ordinance (Cap. 127) were banished from the Colony in the second half of 1957.

    Mr E. B. David: The answer is two persons, Sir.

BANISHMENT ORDINANCE
(Banishment delay)


    19. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Chief Secretary whether any persons against whom orders of banishment were issued under the Banishment Ordinance (Cap. 127) more than three months ago, have not, in fact, been as yet banished from the Colony; and whether he will state the reasons for the delay in banishing them.

    Mr E. B. David: Yes, Sir. There have been unexpected difficulties in the matter of shipping arrangements of these banishees, but efforts are being made to resolve them.

PRESERVATION OF PUBLIC SECURITY ORDINANCE
(Re-enactment after expiry)


    20. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Chief Secretary whether Government proposes to introduce legislation for the re-enactment of the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance (No. 25 of 1955), which expires on 20th October, 1958.

    Mr E. B. David: Sir, unless there is any material lessening of the threat to public security between now and October, of which the Government at present sees no sign, the Government expects that the public interest will require the enactment of further legislation on the lines of the present Ordinance.

INTERVIEWS BETWEEN SINGAPORE BAR MEMBERS AND DETAINEES
(Ensurance of privacy)


    21. Mr Lim Choon Mong asked (Mr Lim Koon Teck not being present to rise and ask his question) the Chief Secretary whether interviews between members of the Singapore Bar and persons detained under the Public Security Ordinance at the Criminal Investigation Department have been treated as confidential interviews; and whether he will give an assurance that all necessary steps are taken to ensure the complete privacy of these interviews.

Column: 28

DETAINEES CONFINED AT CENTRAL POLICE STATION
(Reasons)


    22. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Secretary whether any persons detained under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance, 1955, have been confined at the Central Police Station for more than six weeks, and if he will state the reasons for such confinements in the said Police Station.

    Mr E. B. David: Sir, a number of such persons have from time to time been confined for more than six weeks. They are confined there for purposes of interrogation.

DETAINEES - CONFINEMENT CONDITIONS


    23. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Secretary if he will describe the conditions in which persons detained under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance, 1955, are confined; and if he will state whether there is any separate Detention Camp provided for such detainees.

    Mr E. B. David: Sir, the conditions are laid down in instructions issued by the Chief Secretary under subsection (3) of section 3 of the Ordinance. I will supply the hon. Member with a copy of these instructions if he wishes. Conditions of detention follow as far as is practicable the conditions imposed in the United Kingdom on detainees under Defence Regulation 18 (b) during the last War. The conditions are as liberal as considerations of security and discipline permit. Detainees are not required to work except for the purpose of keeping their rooms and precincts clean.

    There is no separate detention camp for detainees but subject to the availability of suitable accommodation, detainees are not kept in confinement with convicted prisoners.

Column: 29



    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Hon. the Chief Secretary tell us why there is no separate detention camp for detainees, and are such detainees considered as prisoners or criminals?

    Mr E. B. David: Sir, I have already said that such detainees are not considered as convicted prisoners and their conditions are, as far as it is possible to make them, consonant with those which have been in force in the United Kingdom for those detained during the last War.

    As regards putting up a separate detention camp, that would be a matter of building, Sir, It would cost money and we very much hope that it would not be necessary to retain this accommodation for any length of time.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Sir, can the Chief Secretary tell us will the Government then consider utilising some of the buildings that Government possesses to turn them into such detention camps?

    Mr Speaker: Perhaps the hon. Member would like to repeat his question?

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Can the Chief Secretary tell us, Sir, will the Government consider utilising some of the present Government department buildings and turn them into detention camps for detainees?

    Mr E. B. David: I am afraid, Sir, that there is no surplus accommodation among the present Government buildings.

MORE STRINGENT MEASURES AGAINST GANGSTERS AND KIDNAPPERS
(Amending legislation)


    24. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Secretary if he will introduce amending legislation so that more stringent measures could be taken against gangsters and kidnappers in Singapore.

    Mr E. B. David: The hon. Member will now be aware that steps have already been taken to introduce legislation of the type he suggests.

Column: 30

LICENSED AND UNLICENSED DEALERS IN FIRE CRACKERS


    25. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Secretary if he will state, in regard to the storage and sale of fire crackers:-

    (a) the number of licensed wholesale and retail dealers in the City and rural areas;

    (b) what steps have been or will be taken against unlicensed dealers; and

    (c) whether any Court action has been instituted against:-

    (i) unlicensed dealers for storage; and

    (ii) licensed retail dealers for storage in excess of the quantity permitted in their licences;

    and the number, if any, of such dealers prosecuted in each case.

    Mr E. B. David: Sir, in the City area, there are 13 wholesale and 222 retail licensed dealers. In the rural areas, there is one wholesale licensed dealer. Retail dealers in the rural areas have only been required to be licensed since 6th March this year and no licence has yet been issued.

    In reply to the second part of the question, summonses have been issued.

    In reply to the third part, the answer is yes in both cases. At the time of the recent New Year celebrations, 25 summonses were issued for unlicensed storage, and two for storage in excess of permitted quantity.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Can the Chief Secretary tell us will Government consider banning all fire crackers in Singapore?

    Mr E. B. David: Unless there is very substantial evidence, Sir, that the majority of the community affected desires such a step, the Government has no such intention.

Column: 31

BANNING OF STRIP-TEASE SHOWS AND
WITHDRAWAL OF EXISTING LICENCES


    26. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Secretary if he will consider introducing legislation to ban all striptease shows in Singapore; and if he will cause all existing licences issued to be withdrawn forthwith.

    Mr E. B. David: Sir, such shows are already forbidden. The terms of the licences granted by the police to female actresses in Singapore preclude the removal of any clothing during the actual performances, or the making of any indecent or improper gesture, action or speech. The conditions of the licence also require that the actress herself is adequately clothed and that none of her clothes shall be transparent or flesh coloured.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Sir, does not the Chief Secretary feel that strip-tease is a moral threat to the people of Singapore which initiated the statement by Mrs Shirin Fozdar?

    Mr Speaker: It is a matter of opinion.

PAWNBROKERS (AMENDMENT) ORDINANCE, 1957
(Reasons for delayed implementation)


    27. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Secretary if he will give the reasons for the delay in implementing the Pawnbrokers (Amendment) Ordinance, 1957, passed by the Assembly on 25th April, 1957, and assented to on 10th May, 1957.

    Mr E. B. David: Sir, the Ordinance could not be brought into force until the rules for carrying out the provisions had been made, and the drafting of appropriate rules took longer than expected. As the hon. Member is probably aware, the Ordinance and the rules were brought into force on 1st April. The Licensing Board has already called for applications.

INDONESIAN CRISIS
(Statement on Government stand)


    28. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Secretary if he will make a statement on the stand of the Singapore Government towards the Indonesian crisis;

Column: 32

and what steps the Government has taken to prevent Indonesians having political connections with the Indonesian crisis from entering this country under the guise as businessmen.

    Mr E. B. David: Sir, the present disturbances in Indonesia are purely an internal affair and the Singapore Government will abstain from any act which may be construed as, or may appear to be, interference in the internal affairs of another state. It is not the intention of the Government to deny right of entry into Singapore to persons who are in possession of valid travel documents so long as their presence is not prejudicial to the peace and orderly government of Singapore.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Is the Chief Secretary aware that these persons coming in as businessmen are in fact having political connections with the Indonesian crisis?
